contents.context:
Frontline medical staff battling the pandemic in the summer heat here in South Korea will get ice jackets to keep them safe and cool.
The Korean Nurses Association plans to deliver around five-thousand jackets to almost six-hundred screening stations and hospitals treating COVID-19.
Medical staff will wear the cooling jackets inside their protective suits.
The South Korean government also plans to come up with similar measures to keep healthcare workers cool in the hot weather.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Korean Nurses Association provides COVID-19 medical staff with ice jackets
Updated: 2020-06-12 17:07:55 KST

contents.context:
The United States is planning to withdraw its troops from South Korea and other ally nations.
That's according to former U.S. ambassador to Germany, Richard Grenell, in an interview with German daily 'Bild Zeitung.
He said that the Trump administration has a long term plan to remove U.S. troops from countries including South Korea, Japan, and Iraq.
The Trump administration has already begun talks to reduce its military presence in Iraq.
However, South Korea's defense ministry said in response that no discussions have taken place between Seoul and Washington about a possible troop withdrawal.
Reporter : peterwjchoi@gmail.com
contents.headline:
U.S. government plans to withdraw troops from S. Korea, other ally nations
Updated: 2020-06-12 17:06:50 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in spoke with his counterpart in Honduras, President Juan Orlando Hernandez, over the phone today about boosting bilateral cooperation.
Moon said that Honduras could link its e-government project with South Korea's New Deal initiative in the digital sector.
Hernandez said it would benefit the entire Latin America if South Korea were to invest in Honduras' public transport and digital government plans.
Thanking South Korea for joining the Honduras-based Central American Bank for Economic Integration, the Honduras president invited President Moon to visit his country.
The two leaders vowed to step up bilateral communication.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Honduras asks for S. Korea's cooperation in e-government project
Updated: 2020-06-12 17:06:38 KST

contents.context:
The South Korean government announced on Friday it would extend its COVID-19 prevention guidelines for the Seoul metropolitan area after a series of cluster infections in the capital region.
The measure was initially set to come to an end this Sunday but now it has been extended indefinitely.

"There is no end date to this and it will remain until the new confirmed cases are in the single digits."

The measure comes as around 96-percent of local infections over the past two weeks came from the capital area.
The government will expand its definition of 'high-risk facilities' to include more places other than the 8 types of facilities already following extra measures.
It will also take stricter legal action against businesses that don't follow the law.
QR codes or "quick response codes" will become mandatory for private education facilities and Internet cafes to keep track of visitors at high-risk facilities.
But the government has decided not to go back to stronger social distancing measures like preventing students from going to school, as those stronger measures could harm children's education and people's livelihoods.
The Education Ministry also aligned its policies with the government by extending until June 30th its limit that caps schools in the capital area at one-third capacity.
On Friday, South Korea reported 56 new COVID-19 cases of which 43 were community transmissions.
There was one new deathbringing the death toll to two-hundred-77.
Now, the total number of cases in South Korea stands at twelve,3.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to extend strengthened measures to stop COVID-19 spread
Updated: 2020-06-12 17:03:23 KST

contents.context:
The South Korean government says the date and location of the highly anticipated launch of its first military communications satellite have not yet been set.
That's contrary to U.S. media reports, which cite industry sources as saying that the satellite, dubbed Anasis-two, could lift off next month on a Falcon 9 rocket launched by SpaceX, the commercial space firm.
But South Korea's Defense Acquisition Program Administration said Friday that the details of the launch will depend on many factors, including the weather.
The Anasis-two is expected to provide more secure communications and wider coverage compared to civilian-owned satellites, which the South Korean military currently relies on for communications.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Launch date of S. Korea's first military satellite not yet fixed: Gov't
Updated: 2020-06-12 13:46:46 KST

contents.context:
As the COVID-19 situation is still causing concern in the Seoul metropolitan area, the government has decided to extend its period of strengthened measures.
Prime Minister Chung Sye-kyun held a briefing on Friday to announce that this decision is inevitable and will last until the situation improves.
The government is advising people not to visit places like bars and is restricting events with mass gatherings.
This move first was initiated in late May, when the government shut down public facilities like museums and parks and advised private education institutions and bars to close until June 14th.
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to extend strengthened measures to stop COVID-19 spread
Updated: 2020-06-12 10:31:15 KST

contents.context:
The island of Jeju, just off the coast of the Korean peninsula, was formed by volcanic eruptions.
Its unique geological features and natural beauty, make it a popular destination for domestic tourism, even more so with the halt in overseas travel.

The tuff cone of Seongsan Ilchulbong or Seongsan Sunrise Peak is one of the island's most iconic spots.
Rising out from the ocean, the sea cliffs offer a view that cannot been seen in other volcanic cones around the island.
It's also known for its scientific value given its well-preserved bowl-shaped crater and the inner structures of a hydrovolcano, which is why it is designated a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It takes roughly 20 minutes to reach the peak, where you can enjoy one of the most spectacular sunrises in the country.

"I was really impressed when I came here for a school trip. I wanted to come here with my kid as the hiking course is not that tough either."

The volcanic activities have also created this estuary, where fresh water meets with the ocean.
The tide's ebb and flow can even be seen in this lake.
And in the afternoon, the water level goes down by up to 2 meters.

"Tourists can also take a ride on one of Jeju's traditional fishing boats, known as Taewoo. The wooden boats were once used by haenyo, or the island's iconic female divers."
And people can use kayaks to get up close to the volcanic cliffs.

But Manjanggul cave may offer a truly exceptional experience, taking you into the actual passageways that lava once flowed through.
Meaning "very deep" in local dialogue, the tunnel shows the delicate footprints of the lava flow, from which its direction and thickness can be estimated.

"I’ve been to other caves before but I’ve never seen one this big."

Some 170 volcanic caves have been discovered so far, of which four are open to the public.

Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang News, Jeju.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Volcanic wonders of Jeju attracting domestic tourists
Updated: 2020-06-12 10:06:49 KST

Gov't COVID-19 briefing
Updated: 2020-06-12 10:03:34 KST

contents.context:
Let's start with the latest on the coronavirus situation in South Korea.
The country reported 56 new cases of COVID-19 on Friday, with most of them in Seoul and its surrounding areas.
Of the new cases, 43 were community transmissions.
Thirteen were imported, of which 10 were found at quarantine checkpoints.
Twenty-five cases were reported in Seoul and 19 in Gyeonggi-do Province.
The total number of cases now stands at twelve,3.
There was one new death, bringing the death toll to two-hundred-77.
More than 24-thousand people are currently being tested.
Reporter :
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 56 new COVID-19 cases on Friday, 1 new death
Updated: 2020-06-12 10:01:47 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's jump in new coronavirus cases from local cluster infections has been spreading quickly in the Seoul metropolitan area, forcing the government to extend its virus prevention guidelines, initially set to come to an end this Sunday.
This as the health minister does not see an improvement in the COVID-19 situation in the metropolitan area, compared to that of two weeks ago.
Our Jang Tae-hyun is in line to tell us more.
Tae-hyun, what is going to happen?

Health Minister Park Neung-hoo held a briefing on Friday to announce that the strengthened prevention measures in the capital area will be extended.
Take a listen.

"There is no end date to this and it will remain until the new confirmed cases are in the single digits."

He added that the government will make every effort to stop the spread; take legal actions when businesses don't abide by the law, and increase the supply of thinner masks.
The government is advising people not to visit places like bars and is restricting events with mass gatherings.
This move first was initiated in late May, when the government shut down public facilities like museums and parks and advised private education institutions and bars to close until June 14th.
Such measures come as since the start of June, 97 percent of new cases were concentrated in the Seoul metropolitan area.
Several cluster outbreaks including cases at a door-to-door sales company and an indoor table tennis gym have sparked concerns for health authorities.
The cluster infection related to a table tennis club in southwestern Seoul has also led to infections at a welfare center for senior citizens.
Since Seoul and nearby areas are densely populated, it's crucial to follow the COVID-19 prevention guidelines to stop the spread of the virus.
Back to you, Mark
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to extend strengthened measures to stop COVID-19 spread
Updated: 2020-06-12 10:00:28 KST

contents.context:
South Korea continues to grapple with the spread of the coronavirus, with most cases concentrated in the Seoul metropolitan area.
On top of major cluster infections including Richway, a door-to-door sales company in Seoul and an indoor table tennis gym, there are also sporadic cluster outbreaks that have sparked new concerns for quarantine authorities.
They are deeply worried about the difficulty they have keeping up with the speed of infections spreading across the community.

"We are currently tracing after outbreaks. The ongoing infection and transmission routes will be crucial in setting future quarantine responses."

The South Korean government has been reviewing the effectiveness of intensified life quarantine measures in Seoul, Incheon and Gyeonggi-do Province, which is scheduled to run through June 14th.
Its final decision is due Friday.
Such measures come as in June alone, 97 percent of new cases were concentrated in the Seoul metropolitan area.
As of Thursday, all of the 40 locally transmitted cases were in the metropolitan area.

"We see sporadic cluster infections at various venues, including small religious group meetings, a door-to-door sales company and a table tennis club."

Cases tied to Richway are on the rise, leading to other clusters as well.
As of noon on Thursday, a total of 116 patients were confirmed in relation to Richway.
The cluster infection related to a table tennis club in southwestern Seoul has also led to infections at a welfare center for senior citizens, increasing to 60 just a week since the first outbreak.
Kim Hyo-sun, Arirang News.

Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean health authorities to announce decision on further quarantine response in metropolitan area on Friday amid continuing cluster infections
Updated: 2020-06-12 07:07:10 KST

contents.context:
Now the latest on the legal battle of Samsung Group's de facto leader and heir under investigation for crimes allegedly committed in his succession to the company's leadership.
A panel of 15 ordinary citizens appointed by the prosecution has decided that there needs to be a review of the probe and whether it's necessary and fair by a panel of outside experts.
This outside review system was set up two years ago as a check on the prosecution's powers.
Once the review committee is formed, it'll take about two weeks to do its review and issue an opinion on whether an indictment for Lee Jae-yong would be valid.
Their opinion is not legally binding, but experts say it will have some influence.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Samsung heir investigation to be reviewed by expert panel
Updated: 2020-06-11 18:04:58 KST
